message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A machine-like murmur is suggestive of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is a prostaglandin inhibitor that can help close the PDA. Digoxin and prostaglandin E1 and E2 are not indicated for PDA closure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The machine-like murmur heard at the sternal border suggests the presence of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can help close PDA in premature infants. Digoxin and prostaglandins are not used for PDA closure. Prostaglandin E1 and E2 are used in neonates with pulmonary hypertension or ductal-dependent congenital heart disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The machine-like murmur suggests patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), and Indomethacin is a prostaglandin synthesis inhibitor that can close a PDA. Digoxin, Prostaglandin E1, and Prostaglandin E2 have no effect on PDA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The machine-like murmur suggests a Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is a medication that can close the PDA, while the other options would not address this issue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The machine-like murmur suggests a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) and Indomethacin, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, is used to help close a PDA by reducing prostaglandin levels. Digoxin is used for heart failure, and the prostaglandins are used to keep the patency of PDA, so neither of them is appropriate in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The machine-like murmur suggests patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which is more common in premature infants. Indomethacin is used to treat PDA in infants, while the other options are not appropriate for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A machine-like murmur heard at the left sternal border suggests a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that can promote closure of the PDA. Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside used to treat heart failure in infants. Prostaglandin E1 and E2 are used to maintain ductus arteriosus patency in certain congenital heart defects, but in this case, we want to promote closure of the PDA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The machine-like murmur indicates a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that can help close a PDA. Digoxin is used for heart failure, not for PDA. Prostaglandin E1 and E2 are used to keep the ductus arteriosus open in certain congenital heart defects, so they are not appropriate for this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The machine-like murmur suggests patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is a prostaglandin synthetase inhibitor that can be used to close PDA. Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside used for heart failure, but not for PDA. Prostaglandin E1 and E2 are vasodilators that can keep PDA open and are contraindicated in this case.

We refer to the American Academy of Pediatrics guidelines for help. A machine-like murmur heard at the left sternal border in a 1-month-old infant indicates a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that can help close a PDA. Digoxin is used to treat heart failure, but this is not indicated in this case. Prostaglandin E1 and E2 keep the PDA open, which is not what is needed.
